awd_titl_txt: IDIEA-DC: An Infrastructure for Distributed Intelligence Experimentation and Architectures in the Digital Continuum: from IoTs to the Cloud
awd_abstract_narration:
This project sets the stage for leveraging the concurrent and synergistic advances in digital domains such as machine learning, high-performance computing, big data, clouds, and smart and connected devices to create new breads of applications that were hardly possible to conceive and deploy before. This can be productively accomplished by presenting this plethora of different domains to application developers as one integrated system, which is referred to here as the digital continuum.  This project creates a testbed infrastructure for such digital continuum with capabilities for application deployments, task distributions, performance monitoring and optimizations, and data sets for experimentation with emphasis on distributed intelligence. The concepts and access to such testbed are shared with the community in order to open new doors for innovative system and application research in the digital continuum as a system.  

Convergence research is identified as one of the big ideas for future progress and investments.  The digital continuum is an example of such converged systems.  This project creates an experimental infrastructure, IDIEA-DC that can mimic the digital continuum from the edge devices to the data center. IDEA-DC also provides productive interfaces for exploring and testing research ideas in support of launching distributed machine learning applications on the digital continuum as a system, such as federated learning.   It supports monitoring and control for intelligent and dynamic cross-layer optimizations with respect to many different parameters including performance and bandwidth availability, energy and quality of service.  Two instances of such infrastructure will be created.  One will be a heavily instrumented cluster devoted to emulate such digital continuum while providing the opportunity for more accurate measurements and closer control.  The second will be a cloud-based deployment.  The infrastructure will be augmented with relevant data sets, as well as libraries for measurements and control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The digital continuum refers to a virtual system that comprises edge devices, local capabilities, all the way to the cloud, and data centers. In order to enable such a view and make it available to users everywhere to deploy intelligent applications, many services need to be availed. 

This project attempted to provide a number of services that can help create such an intelligent and accessible environment for users. 

Intelligent Resource Management - to manage the available resources on a system more efficiently, leading to a better performance, we designed two workload prediction approaches. We leveraged sparse auto-encoding and dynamic learning rate for efficient cloud workloads prediction. This technique first extracts essential representations from the original high-dimensional historical cloud workload data. Then, increases the performance of the prediction by employing a stepwise scheduler with a decreasing learning window.  

To further tackle the prediction challenges posed by the non-stationary nature of workload traces, we also proposed a two-stage decomposition approach. This two-step strategy identified distinct time scales in the workload data, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy. Subsequently, our approach integrated a hybrid parallel deep learning model that combined two convolutional neural network (CNN) layers with different kernel sizes and three stacked bidirectional long short-term memory (Bi-LSTM) architectures to predict future workloads better. 

Intelligent Sampling in Federated Learning (FL) – In a digital continuum, edge devices may require alignments of the underlying ML models. This can be time, energy and resource consuming. As such, to improve performance while maintaining good levels of accuracy we proposed iSample. iSample, an intelligent sampling technique, selects clients by jointly considering known network performance and model quality parameters, allowing the minimization of training time. iSample achieves this by utilizing a grading system for recognizing efficient clients and allowing them to participate in aggregation. 

RLFL: A Reinforcement-Learning (RL) Supervised Aggregation for Federated Learning (FL) using Full and Ternary Precision - In optimizing the performance of FL applications, we implemented services and strategies leveraging reinforcement learning as a control mechanism, to achieve a balance among performance, accuracy and power consumption. 

RLFL employs an adaptive aggregation technique for FL using a deep RL controller. This controller specifies the amount of contribution of ternary models in the aggregated model aiming to maximize the accuracy of the global model while reducing the communication overhead. In each communication round, the RL agent first analyses the state of clients, which consists of performance metrics after the transmission, and then takes an action based on its trained policy. 

 

To test and validate such developed concepts, an ecosystem for system experimentation and implementation of applications for a distributed hierarchical computing infrastructure named digital continuum (DC) was created. We developed metrics and measurements for real-time monitoring of the system and evaluated our proposed approaches for real-world application scenarios. The established infrastructure used cloud as well as a local cluster. 

The project also provided opportunities for training and professional development. During the project, the students gained research experience across various fields of HPC, ML, cloud computing, and IoT. This enabled our researchers to perform interdisciplinary research and build end-to-end systems. 

Four PhD students were involved in this project. One of the PhD students graduated in Spring 2022 and started a new position with NASA, while teaching a part time graduate course on ML based on his experience. The team had a female doctoral student which contributed to this project and her efforts led to some of the publications.
